group_1.narration: I used to think that butter tea was a sweet drink.
It's actually more salty than sweet because it's made@by mixing brewed tea with yak butter, milk, and salt.
But when my grandma was alive, I believed it was@a sweet drink, and I couldn't wait to try it.
"It's just salty.@Mother doesn't like it."
No, it has a very sweet smell.@My parents are hiding it; they drink@butter tea together after I go to sleep.
Maybe out of pity for my crying,@my grandma secretly prepared it for me.
Her butter tea was sweet@just like I had imagined.
"If you ever want more, just tell Grandma."
"It'll be our little secret!"
From then until she passed away,@I enjoyed plenty of sweet butter tea.
"O Rakshasi...@Here is your favorite butter tea."
After I became the supposed Rakshasi@who performed miracles...@the villagers' attitudes changed.
They started bringing me all kinds of things,@as if they were making offerings.
"...It's so salty."
The first time I drank butter tea made by someone@other than my grandma, it tasted very salty.
Later, I found out that she had put expensive sugar@in her butter tea instead of salt.
She sold her belongings and worked late into@the night even though she wasn't very healthy,@all to earn money.
She turned my ideal of "sweet tea" into reality.
"Did you not like it?"
"...No, it's delicious. Very sweet."
I decided to continue believing that@butter tea was a sweet drink.

group_1.textCenter: But just believing isn't enough...@I have to take action.

group_1.narration: This day strengthened that resolve...

group_1.textCenter: By the way...the Lama should live in a better room.
The only difference between our rooms is...

group_1.narration: In the Lama's room, there were many transcriptions@of history and tales, in addition to sutras.
While feeling guilty, I would get lost in@reading them whenever I was cleaning.@Among them, I became interested in...

group_1.textCenter: ...the Mongolian language.@I've learned quite a bit.
These footsteps...@The Lama is coming back...
The palm-leaf manuscripts are still scattered...@I need to hide them before he finds me...
...I don't think anyone will overhear us here.

group_1.textRight: Lama, tidy up properly.@The transcriptions are all over the place.

group_1.textLeft: ...You're right.
So...was it about the Rakshasi ritual?

group_1.textRight: Yes, when will it be held?

group_1.textLeft: There's no schedule for it yet.

group_1.textRight: It's always like this!@How long are you going to make us wait?

group_1.textLeft: It depends on Lord Jataka's will.

group_1.textRight: Then I'll go and plead to Lord Jataka myself!

group_1.textLeft: You can't do that, it's not allowed.

group_1.textRight: Even if you say that, everyone's getting impatient.
...I might explode at any moment.
Think carefully and make a decision about@what's to come.

group_1.textLeft: ...Phew.@Heruka, are you there?

group_1.textRight: ...You noticed I was here...?

group_1.textLeft: Oh, dear...@Have you learned Mongolian yet?

group_1.textRight: You know about that too?

group_1.textLeft: There were clear signs of it being read...

group_1.textRight: ...But Lama, what about Dolma...?

group_1.textLeft: ...Won't you come with us?@There's a place we want to go.

group_1.textRight: Where to?

group_1.textLeft: To the place where the Rakshasi ritual is held.
...We've arrived.

group_1.textRight: This is...
(It looks similar to that cave where Dolma@and I were trapped...)

group_1.textLeft: The Rakshasi ritual is held here...
which means, it's where the contract with@Lord Jataka is formed.

group_1.textRight: Where is Lord Jataka...?

group_1.textLeft: Well, he rarely shows himself.
In fact, only the chosen ones get to see him.
We're just bringing the candidates here...

group_1.textRight: ...Do you not know what's happening@during the ritual?

group_1.textLeft: ...I'll tell you, but only you.
The Rakshasi ritual may be a terrifying ceremony@that turns people into demons.
After all, the word "Rakshasi" itself means that...

group_1.textRight: ...Do the junior nuns from other nunneries@go through this too?

group_1.textLeft: No, they perform the ritual in different locations...
But since the other nunneries no longer exist,@this may be the only place to go.

group_1.textRight: They don't exist...?

group_1.textLeft: They were burned down by the Mongolian Army.
And we received news this morning that@the northern nunnery was also attacked.
Heruka...have you ever heard of such a legend?
That beneath the land of Tibet lies a Rakshasi.

group_1.textRight: Yes, I have...@It's said to be the foundation of Tibet...

group_1.textLeft: Girls who become Rakshasis all fight for Tibet...
And all of them meet an untimely end.

group_1.textRight: ...Has this history continued?

group_1.textLeft: Yes, the power of the Rakshasi has been used@for hundreds of years.
...Maybe it's coming back to haunt us now.

group_1.textRight: ...Can't we just stop the Rakshasi ritual?
It would be better to turn back while we still can.

group_1.narration: I thought it was a good idea.@If the Rakshasi ceremony is stopped,@Dolma won't have to become Rakshasi, and@I won't have to become one of those things.
So I tried to persuade the Lama@to get a firm promise to cancel it.
I never imagined it would turn out like this...
